conclusion: Problem involves two objects A and B starting from rest with accelerations over time plotted on a graph.
Graph shows object A with constant acceleration and object B with linearly increasing acceleration.
X-axis is time (t) and Y-axis is acceleration (a).
Object A has constant acceleration; object B's acceleration is proportional to time.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
Initial velocities of both objects are zero since they start from rest.
Velocity v_A at time t is k*t for object A.
Velocity v_B at time t is (1/2)*c*t^2 for object B.
Express velocities at t1: v_A(t1) = k * t1 and v_B(t1) = (1/2)*c*(t1)^2.
At t1, a_A = a_B, so k = c*t1.
Substitute c = k/t1 into v_B(t1) to get v_B(t1) = (1/2)*k*t1.
At time t1, objects A and B do not have the same velocity.
Consider areas under the acceleration-time graph for velocity.
For object A, area from 0 to t1 is k*t1.
For object B, acceleration from 0 to t1 is a linear function starting at 0.
